number of helpful: 339 of 410 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Ragnarok Online 2: The Extremely Generic MMO Experience.I remember the good old days of Ragnarok Online, with its cartoony top-down anime art style, cool spell/skill animations, and overall fun appeal. So naturally, when I heard there was to be a sequel, a 3D sequel at that, I was ecstatic.-Insert several years of waiting here-Then came the day when I heard Ragnarok Online 2 was available for play. I was stoked. What followed was roughly 45 hours of the most generic game I've ever played and refused to finish. Where do I even start? I can safely say that I've played my fair share of MMO games, reaching into experiencing roughly 30+ different games. In the ones where I could make a character specific (Such as Mage, Warrior, etc), I would choose to make the healer. The most sought after, rarely played, and hardest to solo of them all. I also had a few other friends who were playing RO2 alongside myself. Well, over the internet of course. The whole time we were playing, it just felt like a tedious run here, do this, run back kind of game. At first, I wanted to give RO2 the benefit of the doubt, but after hitting the 2 hour mark, I could see, and sadly admit to myself, that this game was just not that fun, even with other people! During solo play, I found myself just mashing the 1 key to do my basic "Holy Light" attack, or whatever the skill was called. I barely gained another useful attacking skill for practically the entire time I played. Playing with the group however was a more enjoyable experience. At least then, I was able to use my Heal, Revive, and Buff skill.One of the cool things this game did have was the Card System. Almost every monster in the game would drop a card. These cards could be equipped; up to five. Certain sets would give you bonuses, and it gave the game a somewhat Pokemon-esque feel.While the quests were generic, there was always a plentiful amount. Story, Side, Dungeon, Monster Hunters, and more. You never needed to worry about needing something to do.Something Ragnarok Online 2 does that I absolutely LOATHE is having items, equipment, and mounts that had time-limits. Yep, you read correctly. Time-limits. The worst possible feature a game can have. Oh, and the class change in this game is nowhere near as awesome as the first game. You finish the quest and the person just says: Congrats, you're now a X, whereas in the first one, you had a light beam down on you and your clothes would change.Eventually I just got to a point where I said "I'm done." RO2 eventually becomes more of a chore than a game. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Quests: As basic as they can get; Split into the trio of: Go Kill X, Talk To X, Gather X.Character Customization: Limited. Pretty much just Hair, Face, and Eyes.Graphics: While it's a nice touch to have Ragnarok venture into the 3D world, it lacks the detail of the original. From character models to environments to monsters, everything is very, VERY, bland and lackluster. One thing I will give RO2 is that it is quite colorful.Gameplay: Auto-Attack or Mash 1st Skill in HotBar.Monsters: RO2 definitely took the easy way out with its creatures, having many of the same monster models with varying color schemes.Sound: Nothing really stands out as bad, yet nothing stands out as great.Fun Factor: 4/10----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Bright and Colorful settings, A unique card system, and some interesting boss fights just aren't enough to save this overly generic, bland MMO.~3 out of 10~

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												I have been playing this game for since it was released on Steam.Seen everything this game has to offer with a max level character, level 85 (ML35.)[ATM] With the new content being released soon, there will be more adventure's and areas to explore. I am addicted to this game with nearly 30 characters scattered throughout various accounts and have experienced every single class available in the game. Seen the ups and downs of the game. I've decided to stick by this game for better or worse.Everyone that has reviewed this game in the past has experienced some unfortunate bugs that have been long since patched. If you haven't given this game a try and are going by the reviews, judge this game for yourself. This review might get a ton of thumbs down but whatever.________________________________________________________________Due to numerous people asking for me to go more in depth with this review, here we go.---HISTORY---2 years ago this game was released as Ragnarok Online 2: Legend of the Second, a wonderful & more challenging time. Everything was kind of difficult to do and most of the time people rejected you because of not having a specific amount of health for raid dungeons. September 12, 2013, they released the Noel class. December 2013, (can't remember the specific date like the previous one) this game was renamed to Ragnarok Online 2: Advent of Valkyrie introducing Master Level. ***[Side Note, master level is pretty much rebirth on RO1 but ONLY your display level is reset back to 1 (51).]*** With master level, the older content became easy to do. Until the ramped up the difficultly on the raid dungeons, still soloable if you have the right gears and junk. That same year, the korean server closed.October 2014, the SEA server merged with us making the game iRO2 (International Ragnarok Online 2) and a sperate server called "Freyja."July 28, 2015, the TW server merging with Freyja.---UPDATE---The last major update was the remake of Forgotten Payon and boosting the level cap to 85 (ML35). In August they will be releasing Jawaii, the honeymoon place from RO1. Awhile back they said that a marriage system would not be added with Jawaii but according to the "Will you marry me?" event on the forums, it might be added. (Ovvvvvver jooooooyed)---GAMEPLAY---***People have complained that it just a clone of WoW. I have not played nor will ever play WoW so I do not know about that. There are folks on the forums here on steam saying that the camera and movement is terrible. Everyone will exerience different things according to their machines and their connection to the server.***The basic levels, 1-50 are so easy to fly through combat level and professional levels alike. There are EXP events every weekend and sometimes during the weekdays to help players with grinding. Level 51-85 aka ML1-ML35, is just grinding of course you can do the Morroc and Dayr Desert quests to boost for MP this could be the main questline or all of the Daily Quests. This is where the EXP events mentioned before comes into play making grinding so much less painful. The current end game gears is Eddga, the "powerful" gear which was specifically designed for PvP. Most of my friends and myself, have stuck with the previous end game gears Cazar & Himmelmez. Now for the what you can do after reaching the max level, anything that you want to do. PvP in WoE (Guild vs Guild, located in Prontera & Morroc), helping low leveled players, collecting items, taking part in Trivia for prizes, farming for items, gears or pets and so on.If this is not in depth enough for you, just say so. With so much experience in this game I just picked key points and just touched on specific topics. I apologize if this is unorganized, this is my thought process.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												I've never experienced another MMO with this many bugs. First, in order to log in with  Steam there is a separate launcher from the game. This only works half the time and there is no way to manually log in. After every update it stops working or sometimes it just stops working for no apparent reason. Second, quests are bugged. I've had a main storyline quest just break with no way to recover it and no other quests available, effectively making the entire character useless. Google revealed that there are several quests in particular that have been broken for years without anyone working on them. Third, the prices for items are different depending if you are on the Warp Portal website or if you're on Steam. The best deals are on their site. Also, some items expire after a couple of days (which is bad if you can't log in half of the time.)The game has been doctored so that Warp Portal can make more money. In the original Korean servers, there are quite a few Tiger mounts that you could purchase for in game money. All of these have been removed and put in a cash shop were you have a CHANCE at getting them permamently in a box. (There is only one mount available that does not require real money.) Costumes are not permament either. Most costumes expire after 30 days and you need to buy extenders to keep it. Both these items cost real money. If you want a permament costume the only way to get it is by more chance items, or by getting a lot of rare stones to play a pyramid game (which has an extrememly low chance of getting an item.) Inventory / Bank space is severely limited. Only 'medium' bags are dropped / purchasable which hardly have any slots. You will get these at level 10. If you want actual space, you need to buy bags from the cash shop. RO2 may not be a 'pay to win' but it sure is a 'pay to do anything fun' sort of game. Server population is pretty low. No one seems to be socializing. In fact, all the social interaction I had was a creepy guy hitting on me. So, if you play MMOs in hopes of finding some new buddies to talk too, you won't find them here. If you insist on plaything this game, do not do it through Steam. Go to the site itself, or better yet find another company / private server. Warp portal is not doing a good job integrating RO2 with Steam. If the game actually worked as intended I might suggest it for someone looking for a casual game to play with friends (if you don't mind old school rpg grinding) but since Warp portal provides such a terrible service, I suggest trying one of Aeria Games' anime MMOs instead. They have a cash shop too, but they are more fair about what they give you. Overall RO2 is a HUGE DISSAPOINTMENT and I am not saying this because it is different from the first game. I am saying this because of the bugs, Warp portal's poor choice of business model and all the issues I've been having. I've played a ton of f2p mmos and none have quite been this bad. You have been warned!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												This game brings shame to the original Ragnarok, which gave many of us MMORPGers our very first taste of what it is to play an MMORPG. Comparisons aside, Ragnarok Online 2 is still one bad game. Stay away from it.RO2 is ridden with a horrible pay2win system; bugs that never or take hell of a long time to get fixed; unbalanced classes; a ridiculous amount of grinding to earn enough money to catch up with those who can buy from the cash shop; and endgame content that is almost impossible to get through unless you use glitches. The staff regularly release new content and events but leave a lot of the game's problems to the side. If you check their Facebook page, people still complain about bugs and other problems with the game all the time.The community is also pretty toxic since there are a lot of immature players who are super competitive about the silliest things, including sitting space in town. The only reason I stayed for as long as I did was because I had an awesome guild and really good friends who still played, so I was able to do endgame dungeons with a decent party. But when a majority of them moved to other MMOs, there was nothing left to do but leave as well.Just... stay away.

number of helpful: 157 of 208 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												I can't, in all honesty, recommend this game. Although the early game aspect is fun and exciting, that facade quickly slips. Despite easy and quick leveling in early game, late game content is still severely lacking, and heavily unbalanced. Constant gamebreaking bugs, pay-to-win events, poor server optimization, lag and latency issues, incredible graphical defects and compatibility issues with regional settings on your computer make the game nigh unplayable at times, especially after big patches. The Pay-to-win model breaks balance between free to play players and paying players, and the gap between them is offputting to say the least. The biggest problem I have with the game is the ridiculous amount of RNG uses in places where there shouldn't have to be random attribution. Random chances to get an item that once opened up, gives a random chance for an item, and combines with other items with a random chance to get a good item. So many recursive random chances that player advancement is purely luck based, rather than progression based on player activity is unbearable to say the least.There are many good things about the game, but honestly, it's hard to talk about them, when the first thing you think of after a long session of raiding dungeons or grinding was: that was pointless.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												RO2 is the very definition of a generic, cash grab MMO. There is a cash shop involved in which the game will shove in your face any chance it can get. Despite what my profile says about my play time, I leveled up a character to Master Level 1 outside of Steam, because I couldn't launch it otherwise. The graphics are decent and very cutesy if that is your style. Some environments are colorful and quite eyecatching. Players who enjoyed the original Ragnarok Online will recognize a few NPCs, and then become disappointed at how bland they are. The dialogue is very simplistic in order to match a certain personality type assigned to a character. The translation is rough and you can spot quite a few typos. Quests give plenty of experience, so it is easy to level up a character to 50. However, it is hard to find players to run through dungeons at later levels. It's not uncommon to wait up to an hour to find a tank or a healer. PVP is pretty much P2W and laughably unbalanced. After you hit level 50, you can complete a quest to become a "Master Class." This is where I lost interest in the game completely. The game becomes a pointless grindfest. Every time you die as a Master Class, you lose experience (called master points)... unless you purchase an item from the cash shop to avoid the penalty. Players have been leaving and many servers have been shut down since RO2's inception. The developers have put less effort into keeping players interested and more effort into milking as much money as they can from a F2P game. With the community dying, I don't see much of a future for Ragnarok Online 2.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Many people hate this game. Many people say that other MMORPGs are waaay better. I am NOT one of those.They say that your first MMORPG is shaping your online playing. My first was WoW and I absolutely hated it. The free world was too much for me and I needed something I could explore properly. Several years later I bumped into Ragnarok Online 2 on Steam. I was a fresh Steam user and the game had been out for 2-3 weeks when I saw it. Since I have seen the anime Ragnarok: The Animation, I eagerly downloaded it and set forth.As an inexperienced player, the game lead me along perfectly. Some things came along the way, but that made me feel like I learned something and that I grew a little more into the universe. The starter area is gorgeous and I LOVE the atmosphere there. The maps are limited, but leads somewhere. You can't get lost and there's a lot of people around to help and boost you. I have never met nicer people in an online game before.Do you like to play solo in an online game? It's cool, you can solo your way up to the Master Levels (you might need some random help with some dungeon here and there, but no need). Do you like to play with others? Join your friends or make new ones as you play. How you play is your choice.People also say that this is too much grinding. I say it's the same way in every game like this. You just need to find the one that suits you the best.As you can see, I have played this game. A lot. Over 1000 hours and still counting. I vote recommend on this game, since I have a special connection with it. If you find the same, is up to you. I just hope you try it out before trashing it. But know this: I have still to find a better online community than this.Join the family!

number of helpful: 24 of 31 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is probably one of the greatest disappointments ever when it comes to MMOs. The original Ragnarock was a massive success in the day, where the world felt alive, and the gameplay was pretty fun at the same time. The sequel was in the works for a VERY long time, and now that its been released... Its a pathetic game, to say the least. There was a unique feel of how the original Ragnarok played, and the second game is NOT unique in any way. Its a pathetic attempt to cash in on the Ragnarok IP, while not taking any risks, nor keeping any of the charm that the original game had.If this game came out 8 years ago, it might have been somewhat ok, but its just sad how low quality the game is by today's standards. Its using an ancient engine with low polygon-count, low-res textures, and is filled with extremely generic gameplay, just click on the enemy and mash ability hotkeys until its dead. It is nearly identical to the hundreds of Korean made free-to-play MMORPGs, with the only thing that sets it apart, is that it uses Ragnarok art assets.If I had to sum up the game with one word, it would be "Generic", if I had to use one sentence, it would be, "stereotypical outdated Korean F2P MMORPG that uses Ragnarok art assets"The makers of this game should feel ashamed for being so damned lazy. Thanks to them, the Ragnarok name will likely slide into obscurity.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												First of all, this is a whole new game. Treat it as such. Get RO1 out of your system.If you're still too stubborn to get RO1 out of your shnoozle, then don't play this game. Period!For those open minded players, keep on reading!Here's my opinion for those who are looking to play this game.PROS:-Decent character design-Diversified Classes and Subclasses(you'll see once you've played it)-Interesting Storyline-Interesting In-game features/events( Dungeons, Raids, Rankings, Honing, Pet summons etc.)-Costume availability (you can look different and be different)CONS:-Stale and repetitive quests (too much kill a number of these, gather a number of that, talk to this blah blah)-Boring (when played alone)-Not much diversity in builds( stats are based on your equips in master level/ same equips = same stats)-Some skills in some professions are not worth getting causing a generic build in skills I recommend playing this game with friends. It's really boring to play alone after you've reached master level(based on my experience). Don't get me wrong, I had fun playing this alone, up to a certain point.  The storyline is good IMO, the characters are quite lovable, and the graphics are not that bad either. I suggest you give this game a try. Altogether I'll give this game 7/10.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												TL,DR version : (Sorry Gravity for this review, but I am still a fan of the original and believe you can still make a comeback)Very generic. I want to say "not as good as it should be" but instead I find myself saying "Not good or fun at all." I give a lot of chances especially to something I want to be good, this took 3 mind numbing chances after waiting a while for the bugs to be worked out first. Give it a try of course, but don't expect much at all.Long Version : Running back and forth between 2 characters over 6 times before killing or collecting an item is downright boring as hell. I have played Ragnarok Online the original and it was/is much better than playing Ragnarok Online 2. The game went 3D and lost all value in community and leveling gain. After multiple times of scrapping and redoing the game it should have been much better than this.Time should have gone to giving Ragnarok Online 1 a huge update or cloning the game with a different storyline. This was awful and I cant play anymore than the 8 hours I have pushing myself to like it. Sorry Gravity but you value your profits too much for this game to be any good.Anime cut-scenes were interesting. New card system is not as inspiring. Music loops so much it may have made me nauseous, Running up and down a hill shows obvious bugs that should have been fixed in Korean Beta, none of my costumes fit me (hat was floating 4 feet aboive my ehad at all times) All of the items are timed. Peco usage for 3 days. VIP access was generous but pointless, the people are NOT fun to play/talk with (original has that locked down better than any game)

Product received for free
												WARNING: PERSONAL OPINIONpositives- character customization- easy to play controls- decent graphics- interesting lore if you actually read what the NPC's say to you- fun with friends- easy to advance until around level 35negativies- excessive grinding (unless you like that sort of thing)- you can't drop certain quests like events and stuff, they just sit their and clog up space- difficult to play solo- while the story changes and I find it interesting, the quests still end up being almost the same thing a lot of the timeI see a lot of people complaining that it's P2W, but I've never run into this problem. But since it's free, I think it's fun. I wish there was a "meh" option instead of a thumbs up or down. It's fun for awhile, but once you hit around level 35 as I mentioned earlier it becomes much more of a challange and less of a game.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Did you enjoy Ragnarok Online?Yes? Well, prepare to succumb to the sad realization that this game is a poorly made korean WoW clone that threw in some RO references here and there.Play this game for five minutes and you realize they butchered every single element from RO that made it great. Generic trinity classes with none remotely interesting (remember Stalkers, Creators, or Professors?), terrible stat and skill trees, slow tab-targeting gameplay, and repetitive quest grind. This game is literally any other low-budget korean MMO with poring mobs thrown in there, then had the balls to call themselves RO2.

content:
Posted: January 9
   My Playthrough     The Review This game has been through a lot. First this game was called Ragnarok Online 2: The Gate of the World which was a game which entered beta testing in 2006 but was discontinued in 2010 due to poor reception. Then it returned in 2013 as Ragnarok Online 2: Legend of the Second. Being called Ragnarok Online 2 you would think that this is a direct sequel  to the original Ragnarok Online? Well it is not as it has little to nothing to do with Ragnarok Online storywise so it is basically a reboot. The problem is that it has all the same issues that I had with Ragnarok Online but now it has whole new issues. This game was trying to be more narrative centered than the original but the story is awful. It's full of bugs. And the gameplay really didn't improve that much above the original. Not worth the 7 year wait.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I havent played the game long, however I can already see why I personally will not be playing long just looking at the 'temp' items in the cash shop. 1. Card System I actually like this part, I'm a person who loves completing collection and like it even more if those collections have a point to them. Each card has a set of stats on them that boost your character, and you can have up to 5 cards at a time (You unlock up to 5 slots as you level). You can also upgrade the cards to be more powerful, though this is more luck than anything eles. It takes 5 diffrent cards to give it a go, however if you fail you lose ALL those cards, so if you have been farming a monster for hours to get that one card you wanted and you fail upgrading it, well...sorry. Storing of the cards is also probomatic at best, unless you pay for the card album, your patheticly small bags will overflow with these and other junk you need for quests and crafting. Now paying for the card album itself wouldent be bad except you only get that storage for 30 days at a time, after which you have to pay more real world money to keep it open.2. Storage: this brings us to one of my pet peeves for any f2p mmo, having to constantly buy storage. You will never have enough space, and they know it. want a 30 slot bag just so you can haul that crap around? better bust open the wallet. Expand your bank a little? Swipe the card sir! In a perfect world, this stuff would be managed with in game currancy, not real world money.3. Comunity: I know that gold spammers are the bane of any mmo, however they are not even present here, which should be a good thing until you see the chat. Some of the most annoying chatter i have seen. The chat channels are not even regulated. The filter also does more harm than good, bleeping out half of every 4 or so words it 'thinks' are swear words. So while I do not see gold sellers spaming in the game, I know its not moderation, its just they think the game will tank apperently.There are a few things that are good in this game, and from time to time i run into people who are willing to help a newbie out instead of just spouting off some insults just because i asked a question. So while I did press 'not recomended' let me just add this....Its worth playing if you have nothing to do, just do not spend any money on it because later on down the road you  will regret it.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												PLUSES:Catchy Anime GraphicsOh so cute Anime GirlsFree-to-PlayLow Learning CurveInteresting Variety of CollectablesAdvertisements for the "KAFTRA" Shop arent too bad... really...Low Violence and Little in the way of Adult Content ( That i have seen anyway )MINUSES:Mostly Horribly Underpopulated ServersTerrible, Terrible English Translations...  ( "All your bases are belong to us" x2! )Undersupportive Community  ( Beginning to think the GM's, like the users, are a Myth... )Collectable pets involve hours if not DAYS of collecting "DNA Fragments" to combineConstant server anouncements everytime someone wins a prize or "refines" a cool itemServer anouncements are IN BOLD, ACROSS THE CENTER OF THE SCREEN, and there is NO WAY to turn them OFFUninspired Plot/StoryLow Level Cap ( 50 i think )Ran into some "Game Killing Glitched Missions" on my first day (They have since been repaired, but still, bad form)"Personal Shops" are a neat idea but are absolutely obsoleted by the Auction House OVERALL:   3 out of 10.   ( A big waste of time )                A cute game with a lot of wasted potential.  I think it is pretty clear that the "English" servers are not a priority here ( Reading the constantly poor translations actually gives me a migrane after a while ).  It actually would probably not be a bad MMO for younger kids to get involved in as the "MOBS" are all really cutsy and there is not much in the way of blood or realistic violence, so far as i have seen.  To be fair, i did only go as far as level 20, but i figure: if the game is universally boring in the first 20 out of 50 levels, why should i think that the other 30 will be any different?

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I was a huge fan of RO. So much in fact I did some trickery to get into GOTW beta in Korea. I never bothered with RO II for a while when they scrapped it back then, so I never got into the beta LOTS, and to me, no offense Gravity, but you failed. The system was much better in GOTW. You took a great system and threw it away, and the graphics were better. They could have been improved, but definitely much better than this. The skill system, combat, everything was superior in GOTW and they replaced it with this sad excuse for a sequel. I was disappointed and couldn't spend more than an hour on this game and uninstalled. The size of GOTW's world was much larger, too, from what I remember. This is just cheesy, and lots of crap. In RO's day, using the technology they had at the time, you got a real feel for how big Midgard was, in this game, it reduced it to walking a short distance to get to the next objective/area, basically compressed it so the 14 year old brain of todays generation could handle it. In GOTW, that sense of "This is our world we created, see how big it is" was prominent, in LOTS(this game), it's completely gone. The graphics and environment reminds me of like it was like 5-8 years ago when Flyff came out.But, even if a Gravity rep or dev were to see this they might not be able to understand what I mean.So I'll make it easy:라그나로크 온라인 2 Legend of the Second = 서사시 실패 (Epic Fail) 라그나로크 온라인 2: The Gate of the World = 최고 (Awesome)

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												This game has it's pros and cons, but all around, it's not an absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥game and it's good enough to get people willing to try MMOs, into that kinda scene, it's a pretty good starter game instead of committing to something hardcore or that needs money to play. I see SO many people ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on this game becaue it's not as good as the original ragnarok game, which honestly, you should never expect a 'sequel' to an MMO to be just like the originalAside from that, all I really have to say is that, despite what people say, it's a pretty decent game for it only being such a low GB game. I've played Tera, and as fun as that can be, this game, honestly has kept me more interested in it, whether it was the story given at the beginning between both races, and then merging into one big one, or the diversity of the classes, decently fast loading screens. actual gameplay in itself (although it IS tab targeting), and the difference between places til you hit ML. Yes, this game has it's flaws, but that's mainly within the community of players; A lot of them are arrogant, mainly holding this "im better than you" mentality over people, especially in certain guilds. Yes, there are glitches, and the game gets boring with the unending grindfest when you hit ML, (which i have a ML24 priest, ML 12 crec, and 5 other MLs between 1 - 5 so don't assume I have no idea what I'm talking about with this).BUT, once you get past the arrogance of other players, and find decent people to group up with every so often to take on dungeons and go gear hunting, the game can be really fun. Sure, they could use some content updates accessible for lower level players that don't have the time to grind to ML40, as well as the content for those that are ML40. But developing a game takes time.And for people complaining about P2W, you can accomplish SO much without needing to pay a single penny. I've gotten over 40k gold, full OSI gear and pretty damn far in the game without spending any money on it, since I don't believe in dropping money on a free game, it's just not how I do, props to those that do though, good on them. But paying money doesn't automatically make you a better player than those that don't. And to get far in the game and get the things you need without putting money in, DOES take patience and time and you can do so much without needing money. But a lot of people are hot-heads that just want to jump all these levels so they can say they're better than others, without putting in the time, it ain't gonna happen on an empty wallet, buddy. So yes, if you do want to get to high levels without putting much work in, then you do gotta pay to do so, but if you want to get there without doing so then stop whining about how it's 'unfair' and put the work in. lmaoAs much as I love this game, the playerbase can get aggravating, which is why it's best to turn off all chat features and just ignore literally everyone in game if possible. It has it's pros and cons, it's buggy sometimes, but for a free game, it's not absolutely horrible and unplayable. There's plenty of games out there that are worse. (like Echo Of Soul, that game is♥♥♥♥♥♥)I can certainly say it was better before they merged the two servers into one, allowing less lag from people hanging out in the big cities, Prontera being the laggiest since that's where a vast amount of players are on any given channel. And yes, but over the past couple of years, it has improved on itself and added more content than from when I very first started playing it, which is more than what a lot other free MMOs can say. There's things that can be improved on, such as leveling out the classes, but all around, it's not a bad game and it gets more fun once you get past Izulde Hill (imho). But to each their own.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												An awful sequel to one of the best MMOs I've ever played. This game brings shame to the original Ragnarök, which gave many of us MMORPGers our very first taste of what it is to play a MMORPG. Comparisons aside, Ragnarok Online 2 is still a very bad game. When the game was released in 2013, I've played a few hours and thought that the game itself was kinda generic and a bland MMO but I wanted to give RO2 the benefit of the doubt and I kept playing for something like three months or so (I've probably had around 300 hours of gameplay outside Steam). As soon as I found that this game was in Steam, I felt like I should came here and make a short review of what RO2 includes. Let's resume it in a few words:- A horrible pay2win system and a ridiculous amount of grinding to earn enough money to catch up with those who can buy from the cash shop;- Generic anime graphics;- A lot of bugs that are never or take a hell of a long amount of time to get fixed;- Unbalanced classes and a repetitive combat system;- Generic Quests. A lot of them. Bring X, Kill X monsters, etc.Just stay away from it. This game is a failure and doesn't worth your time.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												The game's good up until you get to 50. It's quite hard to do the Mastery Quest at 50 if you don't know other players to go farm the gears needed or the Rank up. Back then, the quest was hard, but it wasn't that hard. (During the Beta days). It'll take you at least 3 days to get to 50 then possibly quite a lot of time == if you're just starting out -- to get prepared just for the quest. Once you rank up, the gears that you've farmed from the end game dungeons will be obsolete because the base Master equips are incredibly strong.If you really love playing Ragnarok, there's a sense of nostalgia there from the first one. However, if you're expecting the same gaming experience as the first one, you're in for a big disappointment. They took it to the generation of generic mmo's. Still a good time to play, but it's best to play with friends -- or get a guild ASAP.Just a fair warning, once you get to Master Ranks (50+) the game'll change into a HUGE grind fest so be ready for that.TL;DR : I'mma give this game a 6/10. A good time up until Master Rank. A great game to play with friends, but it's still a bit generic in terms of gameplay. (I know some of you out there enjoy playing these types of games)

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Compared to all the other anime based MMO titles this is one of the best. Now mind you, there is nothing really outstanding about this sequel. The original Ragnarok was unique in it's own right, this one however does nothing to stand out. There is a Player merchant system where you can set up a stall to sell items you found, but this requires that you stop playing and become...basically a ♥♥♥♥ing NPC...This feature would have been better if you could do this while offline. The rest of this game is standard fare, Combat is your normal Tab targeting with skills and classes that are the norm for all MMOs. Despite that this is the only Anime styled MMOs I've found with little to no: poor Programing, bad translations or,  currenccy spammers. Mind, they're still there, just less noticable. RATE: +7/10. This sequel isn't as economic based as it's previous, but, it's still an entertaining world to play in.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2013
												[De-Recommendation] Setting my "This is not the true sequel to Ragnarok Online" bias aside. This game plays and FEELS exactly like a generic Korean MMORPG: Fetch quests, do them, mash down your hotkeys, right click, loot all, run back to town. Doing this RIGHT off the bat is a huge turn-off. Would you like to do this for 15-20 hours before you get to your first job advancement at level 25? By then, you'll be able to do dungeon runs and raids. TANK? KEEP AGGRO. DPS? KEEP DAMAGING. HEALER? WATCH THE HP BARS AND SET UP YOUR BINDINGS!There is literally nothing else that keeps the user interested. If you're comfortable with the 'Point-and-Clicker' WoW style based game without subscribing, then this is right up your alley. And it's free naturally. Unfortunately, the cash shop is still questionable. I have not even seen what COSMETICS you can get out of it, it only works with a raffle based system and you don't even know what you're getting. 100 of these points equals a dollar. These raffles costs 6 dollars each. I don't even know if it's permanent or if it runs on a 30 day expiration. If it's the latter, that is sad.The log-in screen music kicks♥♥♥♥♥... But every other BGM is generic. Animation is a bit cheesy. A bit downgraded from most MMOs I see in 2010+.There are people that already 30s and 40s. This game's cap is 50.There's not enough information for all the classes on the RO2 wiki nor in-game, so you can't really plan your build. You're really left with people who made guides on their blogspots from the Philppines. HEUEHUHEUHEUHEUHEUHEUHE! Because it's really important that a Acolyte's Job Advancement are Priest and Monk. And those TWO are very DIFFERENT classes. One turns to a more robust healer while the other one turns to a DPS and Off-Tank Fighting Machine with his fists. Because of course, skill resets costs MONEYMONEYMONEY.I'll pass. Maplestory is sadly better than this. Heck, Dungeons and Dragons: Neverwinter is better than this.3/10

content:
Posted: February 1
												Inspite of brutal reviews I went ahead and downloaded this game. Now that I've binge played for a few days I'll take the time to review in a more positive light.Pros: Character Costume Customization,  nice-looking cartoonish avatars, towns/cities well realized, extensive pet-trainer with many pets, card collection, easy to pick up and make money right off the batCons: environments outside of towns and cities seem half empty, poor quest translations (which effects story immesrsion), RNG weapon/armor upgrades (does NOT = pay to win)If the idea ok a kooky cartoonish and casual mmo sounds fun I definitely give this a thumbs up. The community seems a little low, but the AH is active enough that I made quite a bit selling items already and there are noticable peak times in the cities. The lowest score I could give this would be 3.5/5 stars. Considering that the store doesn't = PTW alone makes me want to give it a bonus half star for a total of 4/5.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Based on alot of the reviews I didn't expect this game to be very good but I downloaded it anyway. I'm so very glad I did. This turned out to be in my opinion a very fun game.  I thought I'd play a couple hours just to see what it was all about. I ended up playing the entire day!  The following are my personal opinions and from the viewpoint of a new player. It must be noted that I've never played the original Ragnarok.PROS:You can have multiple characters. ( 4 by default ) Crafting is useful and fun to advance and collect ItemsGameplay is fairly easy. Did my 1st dungeon solo on day 1. Not alot of aggro for my Magician at least not in the lower level areas. Higher levels may be different.Graphics are very good and cuteGreat community!  A random player gave me for free 4 Medium Bags to increase my inventory space. Thank you!Chat is active with Trades and people looking for a Party to join.You earn special gifts for logging in and also for staying online. YAY!CONS:Music can get a little boring but it does change in different areas. Takes a long time to regen Health and Spell Points.Potions seem to have a long cool down too.

number of helpful: 19 of 35 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
Ragnarok Online 2, the fifth installment in Nintendo's Online 2 series, is a story-based third person action adventure game. Dropping the player into the midst of an epic battle for control of Middle-earth right from the start, Ragnarok focuses on delivering an individualised single-player experience comparable to that of the Dragon Age series. The player meets his/her love interest, the knight Hans Rapad, early on before he is taken prisoner by an evil sorceror and trapped in an ancient castle ruin. Without spoiling anything, the second act of the game focuses on Hans' rescue, and as an avid Hammerwatch player I know that other fans of that franchise will feel very at home here. As with previous Online 2 games, abilities and combat strength is determined by a vast, inclusive skill tree--think Path of Exile, but without an initial choice of class at the beginning of play. Instead, the main character and all unlockable party members (each available for purchase in-game for $3.99) each start with a simple choice of Focus (Strength, Dexterity, Intelligence, Wisdom, Constitution, Speed,  Charisma, Presence, Corruption, Agility, Fertility) and build outward on the skill tree from there. This makes play highly customizable, and gives huge replay value to the game. Combat is similar to that found in the かたわ 少女 series, with fast-paced and innovative combos being the bread-and-butter. The unique combo system allows players to create their own combos, offering even more customization and crazy action possibilities. Overall, I would rate this game a 7.76 out of 10; while it offers a lot of options, great gameplay, an amazing story, and awesome replayablity, purchasing additional party members forces the monsters to scale their difficulty, which means one cannot simply pay real money to succeed at the game more easily. I'm looking forward to Nintendo adding that feature in the next Online 2 installment. Here's hoping!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Ragnarok Online 2 follows the World of Warcraft model of quest hubs and kill x number of y things. It's very generic and seems like it doesn't have a clear idea as to what it wants to do. Like most F2P MMOs it has a cash shop, which as a business model isn't sustainable enough to make regular content patches or even bug fixes. If you're looking for a game to mindlessly waste some time without needing to dish out any amount of cash, it's a reasonable way to waste a Saturday afternoon. If you're looking for a worthwhile investment of your time, steer clear of this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												If you want the fast and skinny (TL;DR): This game is a greedy pay to get ahead WoW clone that will ban you for no reason. Don't play it, especially if you want to remember Ragnarok Online as being good.The Analogy: Divorce. She gets half your money, breaks your heart, and did it for no reason other than she heard a rumor through a distant relative's distant acquaintance's 2nd cousin's roomate that you could possibly be cheating (even though you weren't).The long Answer:Wouldn't work through steam for me, but I still managed to play it. Clocked in several hours (despite my hours on record, which consists of me trying to get it to work through steam) made it to level 35 and tried to look past the problems:1. Clone of every other MMO out there (I know this has been said a million times, but it can't be emphasized enough).  Way to think inside Schrödinger's box after a radioactive element found in said box has decayed leading to a series of events in which the game can accurately be described as the condition of, lets say a cat in that box, after an outside observer has say opened the box.. They took out original classes, so now you have standard sword guy, magic guy, bow guy, healer (and slightly a religious stereotype) guy, and sneaky guy. Also thanks for the crafting system which took less imagination to create than any reality show ending in "wars" (seriously, occupation + wars = new TV series). They scrapped the interesting card system to turn it into a trinket system (Oh cool, +3 strength. Where's my "Immune to magic" or "Can see invisible dudes" or "You can do more damage to this type, but this other type will pwn you"). Type advantages also seems pretty arbitrary, as I've taken out water type enemies with fire moves fairly readily, sure electric does more, but not super substantially so like in the previous game, and some enemies/dungeons are so difficult you HAVE to over level even accounting for all boss mechanics.2. Buying way too heavily into the whole fee to play thing. CONSTANTLY reminding you that you can buy these things for crafting or reviving yourself or to look pretty. Also 14 day limits on things? That's Microsoft levels of greed. Take down the time limitations, people will still spend lots of money at your shop. Also, the clothing (at the time) was random, so you could potentially spend hundreds of REAL DOLLARS and get absolutely nothing you want. It is absolutely the greediest game I've ever played including cell phone games that ACTUALLY HAVE POPUP ADS EVERY FEW SECONDS PANDERING TO YOU ABOUT GIVING THEM MONEY. Oh and did I mention that the clothing is worth more on the auction house than pretty much anything else? So, they complain about buying gold (which I am not for in the slightest, I hate unbalanced games where you can pay to win, and bots drive me up a wall, you're playing the game to PLAY IT, not let someone else play it for you, then pay them for the work), but then they just indirectly sell you gold, with the potential to ban you anyway (see below). Oh and if you want to talk balance, thanks for having a VIP card that you PAY FOR AGAIN, which gives you a large stat boost, and is basically just a monthly fee. JUST CHARGE THE MONTHLY FEE AND RAISE EVERYONE'S STATS.3. The graphics are just terrible. With all the other "free to play" MMO's out there being substantially ahead. I would rather pay 10 bucks a month and get a decent graphical upgrade. So many clipping issues, and camera angle issues... ugh. That's all you could come up with? Even after tons of people paid you 12 dollars a month for YEARS (I think RO1 was 12 bucks). I really don't care about graphical quality all that much, but when RO1 looks better to me, and it looks like you changed the skins on some PS1 game, come on.But then, even after ignoring all these glaring signs they decided that wasn't enough. They permanently banned me for absolutely no reason. I contacted them and said that if a person who bought gold bought something of mine from the auction house the anti-botting security might have picked that up and banned me. Nope. You banned me, and that was the straw that broke the camel's back. I hope you choke on the money you're extorting out of people for a 14 day mount, which in any other game would be permanent.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Ok, so I've played this game off and on prior to downloading it here on steam and got to about mid-level. So here's what I think about the game! It's not nearly as bad as some people might make it out to be, and I think people would be less upset if this game had nothing to do with the Ragnarok universe and just had its own. But obviously that's not the case here. So onto the main problems with the game, the first one being that it's generic. Painfully generic. HELLA generic. In fact, one of the only features about this game that even remotely help it stand out is the fact that it's a Ragnarok game--and in my opinion, in name only. RO2 has none of what made the original so great...The charming pixelated sprites being replaced with generic animu models, bland (and again, generic) combat mechanics you'll find in just about every tab-targetting game, a lacking soundtrack, and shady behavior from the GMs are all reasons why this game and the original Ragnarok Online just can't compare.In conclusion...If you're looking for a new MMO to try and hold you over for a little bit and aren't too picky, go ahead and give it a try. I still find myself briefly coming back to it when I'm bored and up for a simple game to keep me entertained for a while myself.However, if you're coming into this game expecting anything even remotely close to the original Ragnarok, then you'll be very disappointed. Final Verdict: Play Tree Of Savior instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I'm afraid I can't endorse this game. I just can't. I've spent my fair share of hours playing it and I can tell you: It's as dull as it gets. The idea in itself was not bad, but the execution is plain terrible. It's fun for a while, but after putting some time into it, it gets old pretty fast (and you realize it's not going to get better).Most of the classes are pretty boring after some levels, with only a few skills to use. All of them feel very generic and uninteresting, unlike RO classes.You will also get bored of the quests real quick. It's not just the nonsense they put you through sometimes, they are also BLAND and MONOTONOUS. The kind of BLAND and MONOTONOUS that makes you wonder why are you still playing the game.As of summer 2013 it also struck me as a pay2win game, as you could enhance your HP, SP and movement speed by spending money.It pains me to say this, but you're better off playing the original Ragnarok Online. I so wanted this game to be at least half as good as Ragnarok Online was.All in all, the login screen music is great. That, and the Led Zeppelin reference in one of the towns are the only good points about this game. That, and the characters don't look half bad either.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Being a Ragnarok Online 1 veteran, I had extremely high hopes for this game. I would finally get to see that fantasy world I had spent so many hours in in full 3D! ..That's also about it. The graphics are cutesy and really scream RO, and there are a lot of throwbacks to the first game. You will quickly find yourself killing Porings and Chonchons once again, and each of them still have their respective soundeffects I have personally come to dread (in a loving way!)Other than that though, RO2 is just your typical MMO. Although there are definitely upgrades from the first game (Actual quests, flight paths, group finder), it doesn't really bring anything new to the table and is pretty much just your average MMO. Yes, you could play any other free MMO to have the same experience, but if you are a Ragnarok lover or dig the graphics/gameplay, go for it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Unfortunately, this is a prime example of why Korean games and Western games differ, in all the wrong things. Economy based, grind fest with repeatative music from the very get go. While it has a certain charm style-wise (as all Korean mmo's do) it's a pretty distraction at best. It's a cookie cutter mmo....same tired concept of unoriginal questing and there's absolutely nothing inspiring about it. If you enjoy cute things, then go ahead and play....if it was cute and had substance that would be one thing but it's just cute, that's it. Find me a slightly chibi style mmo that doesn't have the same exact play style and quest system and you will have found the unicorn. I don't see how these same style mmo's keep getting made and never managing to be original as they continue on. I've been fooled before by good looking Korean mmo's, Lineage 2, Aion, Rf Online, Terra online, and been disappointed. I guess there's a big enough population of gamers that like these uninspired things.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game.I'm not much for any MMO but the original Ragnarok was a lite hearted and fun game with a great comunity of people and lots of creative astetic and functional customisations.While technically those mechanics are in this incarnation, this game does not use them propperly to get a cohesive feel to them.the voiceovers at (least for the english) are HORIBLE, probably the worst use of voice and animation I have seen in a long time.with the choice of font color your eyes are drawn to the summery for a quest and not the plot dialogue that would motivate the character in world. For me it was so distracting that I on more than one occasion was scratching my head and had to go back and read the dialogue again.some of the quests are simply find a character, then that starts another quest where you have to talk to that same person again.Early on there is a time where you meet the person then have to talk to them four times, this could have been swayed by just haveing an actual dialogue with the person.When you meet the king you are given the offer to become an apprentice knight.then it actually says that your character says yes. removing your choice.In a medium founded on naritive (JRPG) and a style founded on choice and player empowerment (3D quest based games) this fails at both.I love the look and feel of the Ragnarok world. (Poorings are just to cute to ignore) but without a solid story to add richness to the world and more consideration given to the NPCs and the PC choices this one is going to likely be forgotten fast.However I am considering reinstalling the original Ragnarok to get my pooring fix in a fun and lite hearted world. Just because it's 3D and looks nice does nto mean it is better.

												Has some nice ideas, the card and DNA systems are nice tweaks, but very grindy.However it's not only a boring MMORPG, no it's also the one with the most annoying, nerf-grinding quests i ever had to endure.Sometimes you just run from one NPC to another in circles, with no sidequests to lighten the mood, just to talk to them. ALL of them.Not to mention the bugs and typos...There are far better MMOs.'nuff said.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Not a terrible game, even if it fails as a proper sequel to RO.The mouse-to-camera sensitivity is absurdly high, and there is a serious problem with the mouse getting stuck, making interacting with NPCs or targetting/changing targets very difficult (As using TAB is inconsistent at best)I haven't gotten terribly far into the game (Currently Lv20), and they're still adding in new features (Or rather, features that were originally in RO), but the gameplay is solid enough. Animations aren't strong, but the visuals aren't bad. The sound is effective and meaningful, but I don't know about the soundtrack because I always turn that♥♥♥♥♥♥off.Not the first MMO I'd recommend, but worth a try if you have a couple friends. (It is an MMO after all)6.8/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												It's impossible to register through Steam. The WarpPortal account creation pops up but no matter what names you try, it says they've all been taken. So I went to sign up through the official webpage, and all the names I had tried were actually available. Awesome job there. And strike one. Then when downloading through the official site, it failed about ten times before I finally got it to work. Strike two. When I finally got it up and running, I got an error about how it couldn't run alongside another program [@1], and it crashed. These crashes happened about five times in a row and I never got past character creation. Googling found a very unhelpful thread with no answers or solutions, so strike three, it's out. I had really looked forward to trying out this game. I think the graphics look really cute and nice, but I guess it wasn't meant to be. Uninstalled.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												HIGHLY UNDERRATED Game. I see negative reviews everywhere mostly from RO1 fans.Why can't everyone see this game as an INDIVIDUAL game? Everyone is comparing it to RO1 simply because it holds the "Ragnarok Online" title... It's a strong MMO on its own!The reason why it's called RO2 is that it's still based on Norse Mythology and follows the same characters, monsters, and possibly the story from RO1 on a different engine and on a 3D interface!The developers are doing everything they can to make this game better and more approachable! Just a few days ago from when this review was written, WarpPortal has taken over RO2 Development! This is a sign that they will never give up on this game! So don't lose hope, come join us and play with the AMAZING community it holds! (The people here are amazing, seriously)Give it a chance as an INDEPENDENT MMORPG and STOP posting your hate comments!If people started talking "♥♥♥♥♥♥and hate" about you and started ignoring and hating you simply because you're not perfect and made mistakes, how would that make you feel?

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Compared to the old Ragnarok Games, RO2 felt very choppy. Movement, using the UI and how it interacted with the overall gameplay felt very rigid, and just really unpleasant because it felt like it took forever to do things, felt like you were lagging and it would not allow you to multitask very well. The graphics arent bad and it is better than what I expected.Some of the questlines were also not really newbie friendly, it forced you to look externally for answers at such an early stage which was kinda disappointing. This game would be overall okay if the controls felt more fluid and the quests were relatively easier to understand.

												So i loved playing RO1 and had many toon of decent level, so like everybody else when i heard that Gravity Inc. was doing a sequel to RO1 i was be on happy, once finally relesesed my happiness along with my brother and my father (who also played RO1 regurly) was in complete dissapointment. we all have good comps that should have no problem running a game with this kind of graphic, but alas we got nothing but lag spikes and errors loading the game. the graphics we very shotty parts of the screen wouldnt load properly, aslo when my toons would run up hills my toon would shrink as if the areas wasn't built big enough.Now onto the gameplay itself. Firstly the idea of a novice class (which made RO1 original) was missing from the game, and was replaced (like everybody said) and very poor imitation of WOW which started you off already one of five classes taking away an already enjoyable start of the game, and as if to and salt to the wound the classes weren't even built enjoyable every class started of with generic MMORPG skill set, plus like im sure everyone will agree warriors (swordsmen) should able to carry every weapon except for wizardy items (wands, staff etc...) the last thing im gonna mention is the NPC voicing... the historian at the beginning of the game sounds like a 60-70 year old woman despit being more closer to 18-30ish in looks and a man who is more of the same age, and also not big in size sound like a big man..... over all this game reeks with poor quality work, and a lack of understanding on how a MMORPg should be

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												TL;DR: Mediocre MMO, but the nostalgia's still nice for those who played RÖ1. Better with friends, boring alone.As a MMO, RÖ2 is below average, quality-wise. Some might chalk it up by saying it's Free2Play, but I've played better F2P MMOs before; RÖ2 gives an aftertaste of unfinished game, a Forever Beta whose developpers bit more than they could chew. The character design isn't particularly original, and the voices are standard. The graphics are okay at first, but get rather dull after the tenth hour. However sometimes you will stumble upon a beautiful scenery (and sometimes, stumble through), but it's not often enough to make it acceptable. The gameplay is entirely standard; the good thing is that you won't be lost with the controls, but if you were looking for something original/different: look somewhere else. As for the story, it isn't grandiose, but if you played the first game, you might like some elements of it.One big issue in the game, that I hinted at earlier, is how buggy it is, and how little the GM support is. In all the time I played, I managed to contact a GM only once, and managed to get stuck in [trees, houses, mountains, invisible rocks, broken stairs, dunes, out of bound, water, wall, boat, ...] more times than I can count. In one occurence, I got stuck in a mountain; when trying to use a move skill to get out, I warped through the map, fell under it and stayed stuck. When I logged out and back in, I was 3 zones ahead, monsters were 10+ levels above me. Another time, I simply swum my way out of the map, then fell again; same scenario. Although it was hilarious when it was discovered, this kind of bug quickly grew annoying.That being said, if you've played RÖ1 before, and have some friends who did too, you might want to give it a try; despite everything, it's still fun to play it with friends, even if only halfway through.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I have mixed feelings for this game.Keep in mind that I have played and given this game a chance twice, with several years gap between. I first played when it was newly-released, for around 2 days, then quit because of the disappointment of the game being completely different from RO1 and boring. I played it a second time recently in Spring of 2016... and this time I did not care if it was nothing like RO1. Sadly it had me leaving in just 1 full day from how unplayable it was.On the up-side, I do recommend TRYING it at least once, because it's free (to start), decent character creation options, low-lag, the armor is beautifully-designed, and overall the game has beautiful art, especially if you are into the anime or hand-painted aesthetic and wanted to see more stylish, late-teenage, anime-style characters in games. It has a few features which are fairly unique(the card system, job costume, etc), but aside from that it's a very standard point-click-hotkeyspam combat MMORPG. There will be many familiar monsters from the first Ragnarok Online game, which can be nostalgic, and they look beautifully-made with nice animations.I liked the beautiful male NPC "Eremes Guile" as well, who is also from RO1. Nostalgia again (and eye candy which is fairly rare in gaming to be made for female taste).However, even with all of these things that I liked, the cons simply outweighed the pros for me.Also, if you get addicted to all MMORPGs easily, and are poor, I recommend that you don't even try. You will save more money by buying and playing a non-DLC console game than this.The biggest con of all, would have to be the inventory. All throughout the game, before I could even reach the first town (Prontera), I was struggling like crazy to manage my inventory. No matter how much I tossed out useless items or stored stuff in the storage, the inventory kept getting jammed with things I wanted to keep like good armor I could use soon and good/rare cards. At this point, you really can tell that the game is using a fairly aggressive psychological manipulation to get you into buying inventory bags/slots/whatever. It's not "BUY THIS OR WE BAN YOU" type of coercion, it's "BUY THIS OR TOSS YOUR FAVORITE ITEM", and to me, this is really still a similar concept to blackmail, and even for an F2P game it felt like an incredibly heavy pressure. I probably have played every F2P anime-style MMORPG out there, and this may be one of the worst offenders.At this point, I simply just quit the game even though I had been enjoying the actual game fine a few minutes before.This is really a game-breaker for me, and even if the game is an F2P model, I expect F2P games to be free-playable without so much stress and pressured near-coercion. Otherwise I would stayed and have bought tons of costumes since I am a fashion addict in MMORPGs. Then again, if the costumes were gachapon-only (I cannot remember if RO2 was), I would also not buy them.So, if you want to play a game without spending money, and not tossing every precious in-game item you have earned, this is not for you in the long-term.Honestly, the scrapped old version of RO2 (Gate of the World) was way funner even when it was still in-development with many bugs. Mainly because it had no cash shop to restrict your gameplay, and it was actually unique in many ways (weapon leveling, movement physics, etc), but sadly it doesn't exist anymore, because why make a fun unique game, when you can make a cash-grab instead?I really tried to love this game, I want to love this game, I really do... but I just can't stay playing longer than a day.

												Ragnarok online is a free to play anime MMO. It's a very time consuming game with LOTS to do. Though it can be very unfair and challenging at times (I'm looking at you master level test) but that doesn't change how fun it is. I think I spent like 100 hours on this game and enjoyed it all. Though there are microtransactions, they don't even seem like they're there. This game has so much to offer and I don't even think I scratched the surface of it. So anyway yeah get this game. Even if you don't like anime, it's very addicting and the multiplayer system works very well and it can be very fun to play with other people and it also makes the game 100% easier. It was one of the very first games I ever played on steam and it's always gets fixes and updates regulary. SO download this and have fun! :D

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												There is no other game that emphasises the MMORPG like Ragnarok series. Have classes to choose and chain of classes which enables you to increase your arsenal of skills. Quests are straightfoward. Dungeons available. Auction is always there if your storage is full. Huge map. Great storyline in quests. Thats pretty basic but no other game that have originality like Ragnarok.The thing is the costumes,armor,mounts... basically every other equipment//accessories are limited and this makes the exitement goes down once playing after a while. Events should give unique equipment//accessories which are not bound by high levels. To wrap it up the equipments//accessories should have a vast variety so players' characters seem more unique than others which drives them to play for long hours because they want to stand out with their unique characters.People are saying trash about the game just because they can't get a good view//graphics of the game or lagging, blame on your Rig for being low spec. Judge the game by the mechanics or base story.I would recommend this game to most of my friends and hope game Devs could change it up a little to make it more 'UNIQUE". But so far my first time playing the game for few hours was great.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Look I'm going to be honest. Look at my time spent in-game and others giving bad reviews. One guys says its generic, another says its buggy and boring, ect. But I'm going to give you the truth here. I played it for a little bit yes and it gives you missions to start you off so you know what to do and your not thrown into a world although I do wish some MMO's would do that then throw some cool little "did you know" hotkeys or shortcuts to do certian actions during loadscreens but I digress. RO2 is honostly an empty game. It feels empty because not even the trailer can give you a story to what your fighting for. They love using P2W tactics and take a backseat to players trying to grind the hell out of levels. If your reading this and you want an MMORPG worth it then think like a Miner looking for a job. Does it give good rewards and worth the grind? Am I stuck in one job or can I also haul coal or metal refine it ect.? Does mining give me holidays off, medical and dental? This game in those aspects is equal to a parent giving a 5 year old a plastic shovel and telling em to dig for dino bones.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												NOTE: This is my opinions and thoughts of the game and not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research. It is a shame I have to put up these notes telling people what they should already know on to do their own, but due to inflammatory commentry, I do.I quit the game running ym hands through my hair and slapping mself to help make me feel like I was alive again.  @_xWow. Didn't think the game would be bad as I heard the first game was spectacular. Wrong. I got a headache from this game due to monotonous crap, horrible camera controls (spent a good 30 minutes fixing it), and the lack of character individuality. My god, there were five characters that looked the same only that the colors were different. On the topic of colors, they were washed out and muted, more like pastels. The color black does not exist nor does any definition in design and contrast. The little Pouring icon at the top of this store page is much better art than in the actualy game. At least cuter in my opinion.Of the "massive World of Ragnarok" there are only four jobs that the six classes can do. Speaking of gameplay, your inventory gets filled up quickly with no NPCs around to sell to, and you have to buy another pack to make it bigger, but that takes a while. An estimated three hours of playing the game and I never left the local area you start the game in. The chat controls are the worst, spending a good 15 minutes trying to join a public chat from the "normal" or general one I was in and back, especially they don't list the channels you can join and go searchingfor the proper channel name. So what's good about this game? For newbs like me who never played the original Ragnarok, this game was horrible. For elites who played the original, this game was horrible and a big letdown. From many I heard from it's severely lacking much from the original. yeah, it's a new game, yeah it's different, but not a good diiferent.The name brought me here after much praise and this game made me walk away with a big headache and three hours wasted, as well as probably most of my brain cells, most likely after being given a mission to "find the mailbox" (which was right behind me) and given a reward, and then "talk to the mailbox" (again given a reward)  when you click to talk to it. I think this sums up your first three hours of this game: When not hurting cute bouncing things was "accept mission, run to mission, complete mission, accept reward, accept mission, run to mission, complete mission, accept reward, accept mission, run to mission, complete mission, accept reward. Kill Pourings. Accept mission, run to mission, complete mission, accept reward. Kill Pourings."    After three hours....  "Yay level 2" -_- .......  so yeah, I've lost my mind. Game over.P.S.: You can't complete your mission unless you accept the reward so if your pack is full the mission will not be completed. -_-

												How should I begin? First, i already played this game on Steam, some time ago. When i launch the game, a Warpportal window appears,that says that I need to register. The only other option - "Cancel", which closes the game. I go to warpportal homepage and try to retrieve my password. Didin't work. Made a new account. The launcher recognized my user ID, but didn't recognize the password. Made new account on the warpportal window from Steam! (Keep in mind that I used THE SAME mail every time,because the only conflict on the account was on the userID). Finally it works, linked account with Steam. The launcher starts with an update. Few seconds, need restart of the game. Restart game. Launcher needs language update,please restart! Restart game. Launcher updates again. Please restart. ♥♥♥♥in' restarted again and again! This is the stupidest thing I've ever seen in a launcher game.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												There is no other game that emphasises the MMORPG like Ragnarok series. Have classes to choose and chain of classes which enables you to increase your arsenal of skills. Quests are straightfoward. Dungeons available. Auction is always there if your storage is full. Huge map. Great storyline in quests. Thats pretty basic but no other game that have originality like Ragnarok.The thing is the costumes,armor,mounts... basically every other equipment//accessories are limited and this makes the exitement goes down once playing after a while. Events should give unique equipment//accessories which are not bound by high levels. To wrap it up the equipments//accessories should have a vast variety so players' characters seem more unique than others which drives them to play for long hours because they want to stand out with their unique characters.People are saying trash about the game just because they can't get a good view//graphics of the game or lagging, blame on your Rig for being low spec. Judge the game by the mechanics or base story.I would recommend this game to most of my friends and hope game Devs could change it up a little to make it more 'UNIQUE". But so far my first time playing the game for few hours was great.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Look I'm going to be honest. Look at my time spent in-game and others giving bad reviews. One guys says its generic, another says its buggy and boring, ect. But I'm going to give you the truth here. I played it for a little bit yes and it gives you missions to start you off so you know what to do and your not thrown into a world although I do wish some MMO's would do that then throw some cool little "did you know" hotkeys or shortcuts to do certian actions during loadscreens but I digress. RO2 is honostly an empty game. It feels empty because not even the trailer can give you a story to what your fighting for. They love using P2W tactics and take a backseat to players trying to grind the hell out of levels. If your reading this and you want an MMORPG worth it then think like a Miner looking for a job. Does it give good rewards and worth the grind? Am I stuck in one job or can I also haul coal or metal refine it ect.? Does mining give me holidays off, medical and dental? This game in those aspects is equal to a parent giving a 5 year old a plastic shovel and telling em to dig for dino bones.

												Eh....tried it out after RO1....bitterly dissapointed with the back and forthing of gather/slayer quests. Feels like there is WAY more room for improvement.3/10: Could be helluva lot better but if you're just looking for an 'MMO' with a lot of killing and back and forthing this could be your lucky day. Personally RO1, a 2.5D game is better, more crafted and even though it's theoretically a grind game...just so betterly executed.

												I'll keep review short. I had fun for most of my time in the game, however for longer playing it's not a good game.If you want something for less than 30 hours, I can say you can try this game.Generic... fine 3D graphics, couple of classes and possibilities.Some quests points bad spots... but they are anti-inspirational (talk to NPC, find/run for mob spawn area, kill that X times (or wait till something drops), return to NPC).Very repetitive, especially after 25 levels.They have quests for beating some higher tier monsters, which need cooperation between players... it needs more than 1 player to beat - and it was quite problematic to get those done, because of lack of low-level players...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												If you enjoy old school MMOs, small MMOs and MMOs in an anime style this is a game for you. Unlike the first Ragnarok the game is far less grindy, however in comparrison to let's say Tera and Guild Wars 2 leveling up still takes quite a long time. While most quests are "kill this" I still find myself enjoying them. There's only one server and the community seems just fine. Just a few days ago I helped someone by giving them potions, they gave me a blue staff and then I teamed up with a group killing a world boss. Having in mind that I'm completely new and this game doesn't have a lot of new comers I did not expect to get into groups at all. If you're unsure whether the game is for you or not, the download is only 5GB, so you might as well try it :)

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Too big of a paywall. I understand f2p games charging money. I'm the first person to defend a company when people complain they can't do everything for free. The company has to make money. That benefits not only the company, but the consumer. The more money they have to invest into their product means the more money they can spend to develop new classes, dungeons, zones, quests, etc. With that said, I think the paywall for this game comes too soon, and it is too restrictive. Lots of companies no the free to play model excellently. Albion Online is b2p but f2pafter.I don't mind cosmetics, but I do mind items that gives n advantage that a non player can't combat, plain and simple. Otherwise it is a good game. If you're well off with money and don't mind spending money on the game you love, then I say give Ragnarok 2 on line a try. But honestly, if you don't mind, and even enjoy older graphics, gives Rangarok Online a try instead.
